posts.name: John Veness
posts.cooked: Dynamically expand it, or have a little button (which maybe only appears when the text has reached four lines) to expand to temporary full window text box, with another icon to restore to normal size.

I came here to make the same suggestion and found this thread. In terms of implementation, the way I see it, as soon as the text of the message being written requires scrolling, the height of the text box should automatically and progressively increase to avoid scrolling until it reaches 60% of the height of the screen, at which point scrolling is enabled instead of increasing the height of the textbox.

I think the text box should not be fullscreen for two reasons. The first reason is that it would feel too much like a new page/window within the app, which would increase its perceived complexity in my opinion, especially if a button needs to be used to access that window. The second reason is that keeping the text box on the page of the conversation and allowing the user to see the conversation at the top of the textbox (the 40% of remaining space at the top), enables us to show an animation if a new message has been received in the conversation while the user was typing (for example an arrow pointing to the bottom then fading out)

For this reason, (and also to ease the reading of the previous messages, for example to reference them, which has a higher likelihood to happen in this situation when the user is typing a long message) removing the focus from the message text box should take the height of the textbox back to its original height.

JohnVeness:

have a little button (which maybe only appears when the text has reached four lines) to expand to temporary full window text box

This one seems ideal. Here in the forums there is a little icon for the purpose:

fullscreen_toggle_button_plus_resize_subwindow_grabhandle1102×111 10.7 KB

Once the textarea hits the beginning of the fourth line-of-data-entry, the grabhandle and the tap-to-full-screen things could appear.

reddy:

as soon as the text of the message being written requires scrolling, the height of the text box should automatically and progressively increase to avoid scrolling until it reaches 60% of the height of the screen

This is possible… but I would rather mimic the current behavior, which is that when you hit the 5th line-of-data-entry, the scrollbar appears.

However, if the enduser has previously adjusted their grabhandle… such as, for example, dragged it to a point which fills 60% of their screen in the past… in THAT case signalapp should auto-grow the send-message-textbox up to the height of the most recent grabhandle expansion. Because there is a separate fullscreen-toggle, it makes sense to limit the grabhandle’s reach to a maximum value of 80% of the screen or something (so that endusers do not get stuck with the grabhandle at 99% of the height and have trouble grabbing it and pulling it down … because their notification-tray keeps opening instead for instance). But the default would be, NOT to auto-grow beyond 4 lines, until the enduser has manually indicated they want that by adjusting the grabhandle.

reddy:

the text box should not be fullscreen … first reason is that
it would feel too much like a new page/window within the app

We have a thing like that already though: when a long message is received, the chat-history has a “Read More” button, which opens the long message into a new-window-within-the-app. It makes sense that one can compose in exactly that kind of window, since that is how the long message will be viewed by smartphone-recipients, right?

reddy:

which would increase its perceived complexity in my opinion, especially if a button needs to be used to access that window

Yes, it does add a button. The button would not appear until the enduser actually typed in a long enough message that they would either get the scrollbar, or have to tap the fullscreen-toggle, or have to adjust the textarea-height via the OTHER button. But I don’t think this is complex, because web-forums and webmail clients and various other kinds of software have fullscreen-mode. So does signalapp, with ReadMore.

It adds visual complexity, we would need to find a place to cram in the “extra” button in the UI, and space is always a constraint on smartphone screens. But I don’t think it adds much in terms of cognitive-load-complexity. If we come up with a good icon for the toggle-into-fullscreen-compose-mode button, we can use that same icon as the “read more” thing when a recipient wants to view the full message in fullscreen-mode.

reddy:

keeping the text box on the page of the conversation and allowing the user to see the conversation at the top of the textbox (the 40% of remaining space at the top), enables us to show an animation if a new message has been received

What about the notification-popups? When she is composing a long message to Bob in fullpage-mode, my expectation is that new messages from Bob would cause a notification-popup to appear, just as if Alice had switched from her conversation with Bob to her groupchat with Chuck or something. I’m not sure if we should allow quick-reply from the notification-popup, though, or if that would interfere with the currently-being-composed message in the fullscreen-mode subwindow?

reddy:

removing the focus from the message text box
should take the height of the textbox back to its original height

Yes, excellent point. If Alice has adjusted the grabhandle to 50% and she starts scrolling around in the chat-history, the send-message-textarea should auto-shrink back to four-lines-plus-a-scrollbar, until Alice taps it again. Where ever Alice was last typing, i.e. her text-cursor in the compose-area, should remain centered during the auto-shrink

Thanks for this, you convinced me. I think what you describe would be the best option if the Signal team is willing/able to implement this full experience. If the experience can only be implemented partially because of budget constraints, then I would tend to think that if only one thing has to be picked, it would be better to pick auto-sizing over manually resizing the send-message-textbox from an ease is of use and user experience perspective, however in my opinion your comprehensive vision would be by far the best solution.

For the new window, I agree that there is already such a window to read long messages anyway. And I agree that the key factor will be finding a neat icon for the button. What about showing an oblique double arrow (line going from the upper left to the bottom right, with an arrow at both ends) just at top of the “+” sign already appearing when a message is being typed. It could also be a double arrowed cross (with four arrows total, one at every edge). Right now, there is an empty space anyway on top of this “+” sign when the message becomes a multi-line message. I like your idea of making the full screen button appear only when the message is getting long, and I think this would be a natural solution since this empty space only appears when a message is getting long.

There could be a color animation highlighting this fullscreen button two or three times for a few seconds when the fullscreen button appears because the message is getting long. The animation I have in might is moving the button from the grey color to the color of the conversation and vice versa 2 or 3 times, as a way to suggest the user opening the fullscreen mode. At the very least for the first 10 times a long message is being composed after the feature is shipped, as a way to educate the user.

You also make a very good point when you say that notifications allow the user to see new messages. I personally think that keeping the current behavior allowing the user to reply from the notification would not be a usability problem.

It is exciting to imagine that after being a poor man in the area of long-text messages handling (not so long ago it wasn’t possible to send a text message longer than 2000 caracters or so), Signal could very well end up providing the sweetest experience in existence for writing and reading long messages. What a development!

reddy:

if only one thing has to be picked, it would be better to pick auto-sizing

Yes, although I would posit there is no need to pick only one thing:

  • implement the auto-sizing, and then later,
  • add the grabhandle, and then later,
  • add the fullscreen toggle, and so on.

Incremental implementation for the win :-)

reddy:

[fullscreen toggle icon could be]…
oblique double arrow (line going from the upper left to the bottom right

The forum-software uses that, except upper-right-to-bottom-left. Firefox F11-to-fullscreen also has a toolbar-icon that is upper-right-to-bottom-left, like the forum. However, youtube has a different thing, they use four-corners like this ==

Once you have full-screened, I think there is another icon which has the same little four corner things, except each rotated 180 degrees to be “back to window’d mode”

reddy:

making the full screen button appear [dynamically] … would be a natural solution since this empty space only appears when a message is getting long

Yes, exactly… just when we are about to need the screenspace, it becomes available. So we don’t clutter up the flow of shorter messages with a useless-in-that-situation button

reddy:

I personally think that keeping the current behavior allowing the user to reply from the notification would not be a usability problem

I agree, but I wonder if it would cause technological hiccups, because you have a message open, and are drafting it in the fullscreen… and then, in the middle of that, you reply to a popup-notification in the same conversation… so for a brief while you would have TWO draft-messages in existence, for the same conversation. Does that work now?

reddy:

Signal could very well end up providing the sweetest experience in existence for writing and reading long messages

My hope is that we can turn the full-screen mode into a complete markdown processor (not just basic bold+italics+strike but everything). Then people can send each other complex documents, which are still reasonably simple to edit from a vkeyb. All within the encrypted perimeter: composition + storage + transmission + editing. Nice

so for a brief while you would have TWO draft-messages in existence, for the same conversation

Nice catch! I didn’t realize this aspect. That’s a really good question then. I am not familiar with the APIs exposed by Android, so I am not sure how much context the background worker creating the notification popups has access to.

But if there is a way to know the current page on which the user is at the time a notification is being built, maybe we could remove the quick-reply textbox only in the corner case you have described and leave it for the rest (which means only removing it when the user is on a fullscreen message creation page in a conversation with the sender of the new message).

Alternatively, to make implementation easier initially, we could also decide to never show the quick-reply textbox if the user is in a fullscreen message composition page no matter what.

My hope is that we can turn the full-screen mode into a complete markdown processor (not just basic bold+italics+strike but everything). Then people can send each other complex documents, which are still reasonably simple to edit from a vkeyb. All within the encrypted perimeter: composition + storage + transmission + editing.

This is exactly what I dreamed of seeing land in signal one day. I was imagining a WYSWYG XML-based kind of editor, but your idea with markdown is much better.
